pros:
This is a review for home office employees. 

Some truly great people work at the company, and there are opportunities for interesting work, but TJX has a hard time hanging onto great new talent with their archaic policies and ways of working.

There is opportunity to work on different teams and varying workstreams due to the nature of it being a multi-brand company.
cons:
TJX talks a big game about being people-first and great advocates for their employees, but they are really behind the curve.
- Benefits and pay are not competitive for Boston area. Vacation days only accrue after 10 YEARS of employment, expensive health insurance, long 401k vesting period, not a fully paid maternity leave
- No promises for flexibility with work from home in the future, even though the company has done well throughout Covid
- Promotions seem to be based on time worked, as opposed to talent. A lot of lifetime employees have been promoted through the ranks and are out of touch or bad leaders. The culture does little to encourage innovation
- Contract employees are treated poorly and strung along, even when their work is essential to their teams
- Executives hoard earnings for themselves
Advice to Management
Saying "your door is always open" is not the same as actively seeking out input/feedback or having an open forum for change and discussion. Routing feedback through multiple levels of management leaves lower level employees disenfranchised.

Benefits package is absolutely the worst I've had. Pension, healthcare etc. is the bare minimum. Salary is average, then it rests on bonus and share options which appear generous but have high charges.
Management day to day were absolutely terrible. IT executive lacks direction and is rooted in legacy - strong resistance to change. Management style is very old fashioned and dictatorial. New ideas are rejected.
Poor management leads to very outdated technical environment, TJX is well behind the curve on most technologies. This is not a place to hone your career on new ideas or tech - everything is ten to twenty years behind the curve.
Investment in career is minimal. There is lots of internal training available, but this to TJX is a new idea, really starting in 2019. The training is then not supported with strong career investment. Promotion is very hard, largely because there are people in key bottle-neck positions sitting still for very long periods, with no ambition to move (due to previously mentioned generous stock options.)
TJX touts its culture but in fact hides behind empty phrases whilst allowing psychopathic managers to run amok, defended by 'don't mess with the model'. 
Just to cap everything with TJX, in hindsight, I also noticed that this is far and away the whitest company every. Especially up at senior management level, diversity is clearly something for others to practice.
Advice to Management
Current management needs to be stripped, pretty much from VP upwards across IT and replaced with people who have been successful leaders of modern companies using modern technology.

review_title: Needs some major changes to maintain success
pros:
- A lot of corporate focus on associates - activity groups, ice cream truck in the summer, occasional giveaways (cupcakes, tote bags, mugs, etc.) 
- Very inclusive work force - all races, sexes, physical abilities, etc. Most inclusive place I ever worked.
- Socially conscious workplace.
-Flex time in the summer (for most employees)
cons:
- only 3% salary raise for hourly employees 
- Top heavy. There wasn't money in the budget to add workerbees but there was enough money to add another level of management. 
- Their open door policy for raising management issues looks good on paper but is not practiced. The HR representatives represent management over associates.
- There are a number of people that are only phoning in their job - some have been there 15+ years. They do minimal work; management is aware of it, but does not seem to be able to address it.
Advice to Management
Give your hourly employees decent raises. Stop/lessen the tchotchkes and reduce bonuses to give hourly employees decent raises. Unfortunately, when I go to pay the bills, the gas company will not take a TJX tote bag. 

Cut out the excess levels of middle-management. They do not add value. They spend their time trying to justify their position by micromanaging the people trying to do actual work. 

When associates try to raise issues using the Open Door policy, don't just support management. I understand it might be hard to admit that someone was promoted into a position they were not qualified for - but it happens. Admit the mistake, fix it, and move on. It seems like once a person achieves management level, they are Teflon coated. 

Have a good housecleaning to get rid of the deadwood and people who do not contribute actual work.

The one comment I heard over and over from people who have worked there for many years is, "it's not what it used to be".

review_title: Drink the Kool-Aid or Get Out
pros:
-huge, recognizable brand 
-no one actually works and just "goes to stores" to claim all the good stuff that gets sent to stores before the actual customers have a fighting chance
-flex hours available
-gym on-site
-summer fridays
cons:
Drink the Kool-Aid or Get Out was essentially the advice I got here from multiple managers. I can't speak for the entire company but for particularly Planning & Allocations, if you aren't a white female in your early to mid 20s, don't bother trying to grow a career in planning or buying here. I'm not accusing the company or the brand of encouraging a predominantly white environment or discriminating against other ethnicities. In fact, I think TJX has many diversity committees and outside of planning/buying there seems to be a better balance of non-whites vs whites. I am saying that within this area, those who end up staying/becoming successful/moving quickly through the positions happen fit the persona of a white female, who is a recent grad from Penn State or Northeastern and can keep up with the lunch table talks of diets, fitness, Kardashians, and office gossip. 

The fact that everyone in Planning/Buying talks, dresses, acts, and leads in the exact same manner should have been the first red flag. The fact that they quickly promote those who follow suit and learn how to mimic their Planning Managers' mannerisms should have been the second. The fact that the training months have all been focused on "relationship before task" should have been the ultimate red flag that almost no one (and usually those in position of power) knows how to really do their jobs and in fact, focus on "building relationships" (either talking trash about others or asking about weekend plans) with others as the tactic to get noticed and get promoted. 

So, if you're a white female in your early 20s trying to start a retail career and can drink this Kool-aid enough to last a year or so here and hopefully get promoted to at least Associate Planner: absolutely work here. It is a big company, huge brand, and you'll definitely meet girls here that you'll become close friends with. If you're serious about actually learning how to manage and plan inventory and gain skills that will actually help you in your career of a planner or buyer, avoid this place.
Advice to Management
Don't reward those who just know how to talk to people. Actually look at the quality of their work. And for those who know how to talk to people and do great work, look at how they lead their team and how they empower their analysts. 

Stop putting buyers on a pedestal.

pros: you have a job and therefore are making income. at said job you are able to sit in a chair...they had an ice cream truck come around in the summer....there are lots of bathrooms...ya that its
cons:
1. Buyers were incredibly rude, racist, and male buyers were extremely sexist. Also did I enjoy hearing a bunch people talk about how they were gonna vote for trump and that he just needs "a better way of expressing his views" NOT REALLY but that was probably the BEST thing that happened to me there. I would consistently be asked to do things not in my job title, but also got punished for doing said things. I had buyers pretend I actually was invisible...like im not kidding it was like middle school. Im not a weak person but man I cried in the bathroom, at my car during lunch, on the way to work, on the way home from work, and on sunday nights cause i know i had to go back monday morning. My managers did not help me or coach me properly nor did they stand up for me professional when buyers were being UNPROFESSIONAL twoards me. Also thanks for letting a supplier basically become obsessed with me and call me a million times....this supplier also asked me to show them photos of what I looked like because they just "wanted to know who the person on the other side of the phone was and looked like..." that was fun ( it was not fun it was hell). honestly I cant write out all the bad, unprofessional, and hostile thigs that happened to me because Im not JK rowling...I cant write a 7 book series about my long challenging fight for freedom but voldemort and the death eaters of TJX...literally my life was Merchandising Assisant and the Dealthy Buyers. I think they actually split their souls into horcruxes that they put into the supplier samples. Idk It was just a BAD hostile envoirment for me, but it was not that way for everyone. I saw people there who also hated it but I saw people who loved it. Im 100% willing to believe I got a bad batch of Buyers and a not so great category...but also nothing really excuses their actions twoards me it was just nasty and I felt like I was on my own. HR, my managers, other co works couldnt or wouldnt do anything to help. I ended up needing therapy and am writing this review almost 2 years after I have left tjx...because its 11:16pm and im having nightmarish flashbacks and cant stop thinking about the horrible things that happened. I am actually being HAUNTED almost 2 years after leaving TJX...cool...great. If u want to work here thats up to you. I hope it works out. Its not a bad company It just has bad people that i had the unfortunate pleasure of working with for a year a 6 months. Do I suggest it to people, no i dont. Do I think you could work there and have a good experience, sure. Am I still haunted by my time there 100% but such is life. I still remember all my buyers names...I sometimes will spot 1 or 2 of them when im in the mall minding my own buisness and I just walk out because even seeing their faces makes me feel sad. wow thats depressing but its true. Maybe someday ill be over it...but also do people get over being treated like your dumb for being a woman or being treated less than for being black? not sure ill let u know in another 2 years. so...ya...goodluck, you may need it.
Advice to Management
Support you staff, communicate and be transparent. Be empathetic and professional. Also dont be racist or sexist and maybe dont let racism or sexism slide but like...I feel like I shouldn't have to say that...sooo ya...

pros: Benefits are great. The 401k plan matching is solid and vacation time is decent. I loved the people I worked with. Even after leaving the company I'm still close with my manager and team. It's a young culture in planning, so great if you're coming out of college. You get great feedback and the planning and allocation department wants you to succeed.
cons:
My background was working as a buyer for a large and already successful company; I was excited to work for TJX and get to buy on an even higher scale. In the interviewing process I was told that I would frequently be going into market and observing the buyers, working on new product ideas, and finding new trends in the market place. This could not have been more false. 

I would maybe talk to the buyers for about 5 minutes everyday and that was considered a lot. Prepare to be glued to your desk and computer screen crunching numbers a computer could in 5 seconds all day long. If I stood up to go the bathroom more than 3 times a day and worked over a 9 hour day, people were convinced I wasn't at my desk enough.

This is a math job, not a buyer training program. And yes, a computer could easily do it a million times faster, but instead you will have to. You will become close with your team, but to management you're a number unless you bake everyone something every single week. Seriously if you want to get promoted faster it's all about sucking up.

Because this job was not at all what I was told it would be, I left. While working there I got several offers to do something I was more interested in that paid higher. While the turnover for the whole company is low, it is very high for allocation analysts. Usually a little less than half of the nearly 80 they bring in will quit by the end of the year. I day I quit, three others also did.
Advice to Management
Change your "training program" for buyers so it's more product focused. If you don't that's fine, but make the responsibilities of analysts clear in the interview. If I had known the true function of what my job was going to be, I never would have taken it in the first place.

pros: TJX has a great track record as an organization and can offer many things to job seekers (stability, tenure, employee perks and discounts, multi-national experience and name recognition on your resume. TJX is known for having a fantastic company culture within the retail sector and unprecedented tenure among its employees.) The organization continues to grow and post great numbers year after year.
cons:
As the organization grows, employees' experiences can differ VASTLY based on the management of their department. Where it was previously common to see employees remain with the organization for decades, many are now being driven away by toxic environments and lack of leadership integrity. While employees are made to believe that they are the organization's top priority, the simple truth is that employee satisfaction problems and management issues are very easy to hide and ignore in such a large corporation. Below senior management levels, employees are easy to replace and are therefore not supported as they should be when issues arise. Those who remain with the organization wrestle with frustration as issues are overlooked, but remain in hopes that the ship will be course corrected.
Advice to Management
Preserve your reputation and keep your employees as your #1 priority. Don't overlook issues with turnover. HR, ensure your managers are trained appropriately and that they embody the integrity the organization says it expects and requires of its leaders. Don't allow the company to continue bleeding dedicated talent in the face of the eroding culture.

cons:
Unfortunately TJX was one of the most
Horrific work experiences I have ever gone through. The planning department is like working in a sorority but with "adults" , often with children managing children (not just in the age sense. Often times more "mature " managers act out in childish ways such gossiping about members of their team to other members of their team and employing the silent treatment to subordinates when upset). I endured two years of mental anguish at this company, left to feel incompetent and as a misfit though often dubbed with the excuse of not having the right "personal brand" to fit in with my team. This phrase is used often and is employed to ensure that the P&A environment caters to exactly the type of employee they are looking for with no diversification - white, female, vapid , with a penchant for gossip and immaturity . The revolving door of employees that go through this department Is not only what I would assume to be extremely detrimental to the company but also somehow a "non issue" as this is something that management refuses to have addressed . Before starting at TJX, I had received several warnings from peers that had heard similar horror stories from the company but I did not pay attention, believing that such a well respected organization in our community could not possibly have this sort of reputation behind closed doors. I implore you, for your own sake, to go elsewhere when looking for a job .
Advice to Management
Seek diversity in your hiring - this is the most one dimensional company I have ever worked for with each person a carbon copy of each other. Any space for thought or personality diversity is shut down as a "personal brand" conflict that is used against you in reviews. Thought diversification is what keeps a company growing and relevant.

pros: Covered parking garage, convenient to 495, onsite ATM and Starbucks coffee, reasonable cost for gym and cafe. The company continues to make money selling cheap 3rd world clothing that US consumer culture is fooled into buying again and again. Growth is averaging a steady 4% per year - beware potential backlash against TJX if a "made in America" mindset takes hold in current political environment.
cons:
Strategy in place to reduce IT costs by reducing layers of management and moving to Plan, Build, Run model recommended by Deloitte and recently implemented. Many changes in reporting relationships have left a large number of people unclear on what their role is and therefore just wasting time on the internet all day. Very dated IT processes and tools. Entrenched Sr. Management has little idea how to move IT in the right direction. Some nepotism has resulted in young people being promoted beyond their capabilities or experience. Culture does not reward achievement but relationships with the right Sr.management. HR in IT has been tasked with ongoing Performance Management which manifests itself in continuous small layoffs, often selecting the best people for layoff because they somehow don't fit the byzantine TJX culture of "don't mess with the model". Yet everyone knows the model in IT Is broken. Many, many unhappy people who have been demoted under the new Plan, Build, Run model from management positions to individual contributors. Consultants and contractor: full time employee ratio is moving close to 60%:40% - you should be wary of being replaced by a consultant from Wipro, Collaborative, Accenture, Deloitte, Cognizant, JVT or any of the one dozen or so approved contracting firms.
Advice to Management
Culture in IT needs to change. People with nothing to do are draining the energy from folks overwhelmed with responsibilities. New CIO should consider overhauling the Sr. Management in IT - starting with HR.

employee_status: Part Time Sales Associate in Chicago, IL
pros:
Managers/supervisors were friendly and fair. Overall a positive environment, as high a morale as you can expect from a retail job. 

Not part of a union, which I prefer because it meant not having such fees taken out of your paycheck. 

I got paid accurately and on time.

I had a clear sense of what criteria I was being evaluated on. They are big on enforcing policies. Basically, the way you advance into management is by following their rules really well even though they are halfway dumb. But be aware, if you advance into a coordinator or manager role, your main function is to police the associates to make sure they're following all the rules that you probably think are dumb. There is no room for any kind of influence beyond that. If you have a head on your shoulders, you'll be screaming on the inside. But I list this as a plus because it's the nature of the beast. I've worked with companies without clear policies, and that is way worse. Here, all of the managers agree on policies and that's what allows them to effectively expand. 

I reported a sexual harassment incident. It was handled fairly well. Way better than when I was working in a restaurant and a similar thing happened. If you're gonna work for minimum wage, choose a big corporation like this where the managers are afraid of lawsuits. I think that if you're a woman/LGBTQ/minority/disabled you have fairer treatment at a place like this than
cons:
Nobody has a set schedule, regardless of whether you're an associate or a manager. The schedule was supposed to be announced two weeks in advance, but normally it wasn't announced till about 4 days in advance. It's seriously hard to handle other commitments (jobs, kids, classes, doctor appointments) with a system like this. And your hours were unpredictable -- maybe 12 hours one week and 25 hours the next. Sometimes the schedule would be changed after being posted and nobody would tell you that your shift changed. 

They make you do the same checkout procedure involving asking a bunch of questions to every single customer. This means you get scolded if a customer buys something small like a bag of chips and you don't ask them if they want to open a credit card. The managers don't care that they are putting the customer service staff in the position of habitually annoying their customers. When supervisors weren't around I used my judgment to selectively ask only certain patrons if they wanted to open a credit card, and i opened more accounts than most of my peers. But they are more interested in whether you are following the script than in whether you are getting results.
Advice to Management
Either create a set schedule or post the schedule two weeks in advance. There is no excuse. I would not be surprised if there is a lawsuit against them for this soon.
Helpful (1
advice_to_mgmt: Either create a set schedule or post the schedule two weeks in advance. There is no excuse. I would not be surprised if there is a lawsuit against them for this soon.

review_title: Run, as fast as you can, from Talent Acquisitions
pros:
Overall, TJX seems like a great place to work. They are company based on relationships and really care about their employees. The benefits are great, as well as the compensation, and the work/life balance can't be beat. They have a really long tenure because they let people lead the lives they want to outside of work. 

If you're looking for in slower paced environment, and I mean extremely slow-paced, where you work a typical 9-5 and along side some really nice people, this could be a great place for you. Just stay away from Talent Acquisitions all around.
cons:
Now on the flip side, TJX has some issues overall just like any other organization. It is an extremely siloed company, so nobody knows who is doing what or how to partner with other teams on projects. Add a really old-school mentality and a dash of terrible technology and you have a recipe for a really difficult time getting any projects done. TJX also needs to work on a diversity program and take it seriously. When I left it was barely talked about, and seemed to be an initiative to do just to do it. When in fact it is such an important topic with a real impact on the business. 

Now specifically to TA, what a mess. Have you ever watched a dog chase its tail for 10 minutes only to get distracted by a squirrel, and when it chases after said squirrel it runs into a tree because it's so disoriented? Me neither but that is the best way I can describe how Talent Acquisition functions at TJX. TA is rapidly expanding, new projects are being propelled at people who aren't prepared for them by any means, and when you think something is finally starting to work out the senior leadership changes directions on a whim and you have to start at square one. 

Finally, remember all the nice things I said about work/lilfe balance and leadership really caring about your development? That doesn't apply to this department because senior leadership is a stark contrast to those fundamental ideals, and the goal is to bring in other people who don't fit into this company and move people who do out of it.
Advice to Management
You aren't going to fix TA over night but make sure you hire leadership more aligned to your culture.
Helpful (9
advice_to_mgmt: You aren't going to fix TA over night but make sure you hire leadership more aligned to your culture.

I started at the TJX Companies directly after graduating college. The position is marketed as product driven, this is true for your first month of "training" or as they call is "MDP." review_title: Family Leave Policies Leave Associates Wanting More
pros: TJX has a maternity policy, that is a pro. The policy itself needs improvement. I am a corporate associate and have experienced maternity leave at TJX. The description below is reflective of existing 2015 family leaves policies.
cons:
TJX's Maternity policy is complicated and could be more comprehensive. There are no official paternity or adoption leave policies. 
The Federal Medical Leave Act protects your job for 12 weeks following the birth of your child. This does not mean it is paid. TJX's maternity leave policy is contingent on enrollment in short term disability. After a year of service you are eligible for paid maternity leave through short term disability. Short term disability provides partially paid leave for 6-8 weeks. 8 weeks for cesarian delivery and 6 weeks for vaginal birth. Short term disability covers 100% of pay for 4 weeks and 60% of pay for weeks 5-8. Accrued sick time hours may be used during the medical leave portion of maternity leave (that first 6-8 weeks) to cover the 40% gap. 
For the second portion of maternity leave (4-6 additional weeks under FMLA protection) only accrued vacation hours may be used to supplement pay. Depending on the time of year and length of service with the company, an associate may have anywhere from 0-4 weeks vacation hours accrued. It's typical for an associate to have at least 2 weeks unpaid during the 12 weeks of FMLA maternity leave.
Advice to Management
The lengthy policy explanation demonstrates why it needs to be streamlined- it's too complicated and confusing. It would be great if it was a simple as- 12 weeks full pay!

pros: The work was fairly interesting, although I would finish all of it within 2 hours and then have 6 hours with nothing to do. cons:
Micro-management; no potential for growth. I interned there for 6 months. After 6 months of great performance reviews, I asked my boss for a raise. (Was making $15 / hour with no benefits). He said he couldn't authorize it - talk to his boss. So I did. After a 10 minute conversation about BS small talk, his boss finally dropped the PC/corporate crap long enough to intimate to me that I would have to wait around for 3-4 YEARS before being considered a full-time employee because my boss's department was not ready to expand. The man wanted to keep me at an intern level for FOUR years.... I gave my 2 weeks' notice immediately.
Advice to Management
Make growth opportunities possible for employes. PAY BETTER! This is BOSTON. It's not CHEAP to live here. Your company grosses multiple millions per year. Invest some in your people... (A novel idea!). Loosen up the dress code a little bit. I get it... you're a clothing retailer, but I got tired of listening to my boss tell me how amazing his $3,000 suit was as I sat there in a pair of cheap dress pants, a button-down shirt, and tie. I would rather be wearing khakis, a polo shirt, and sandals in the summer.

review_title: High pressure and catty work environment
pros:
- clearly mapped out career path
- job security
- good 401k and health insurance plans 
- sufficient PTO
- interesting types of work (product oriented)
cons:
- when business isn't good, people are quick to point fingers
- no management training = bad/uneducated managers
- they try to train people but consistently leave employees more confused than before the training. 
- very old and outdated IT systems that impede productivity rather than improve it. The entire IT infrastructure for merchandising makes the job far more difficult than it should be.
- HR is extremely misleading about duration of career path at point of hire
- very high turn over. Only 8/33 members of my new employee class still remaining at the company after only 2 years.
Advice to Management
- improve trainings -- better courses, better instructors. Having an educated workforce will drive success in the future. Focus on human capital development to improve business process rather than lousy, unproven, time wasting strategies that show little to no benefits or progress 
- offer more trainings.
- improve IT systems and the communication between programs
- remember that we are selling clothes not curing cancer
